title: BC Ferries have their ups and downs
text:
the BC Ferry system has many variations. from the big ferries going from the mainland to various islands and especially Vancouver Island. on these ferries you are able to pay for an advance reservation which is worth the expense...if you get to the ferry terminal in time. then there are the smaller ferries between various islands where there is no reservation system and sometimes one has to wait through one or more sailing to get on.

the area is beautiful and the trips are definitely worth the time and trouble and expense.....and sometimes they are the only way you can get to where you want to be.

title: The Museum at Campbell River is lovely
text: The Museum at Campbell River is a lovely museum which contains various interesting items and history. there is history of the area, a wonderful collection of indigenous items, interactive exhibitions and present, current exhibitions of contemporary artists. it is a very special place to visit.

title: The Best Place to stay in Campbell River
text: I pass through Campbell River on Vancouver Island, B.C., Canada often and i have stayed at many of the hotels in the area. last August i stayed at Heron's Landing Hotel for a few nights and was thrilled to discover that in the breakfast area there are two hot plates and the ingredients for guests to make their own omelette. how unusual! i had never been offered that by any other hotel anywhere (and i travel a lot). there was grated cheese, green onions, red peppers, etc., all cut up and ready for use. it was wonderful to be able to eat an omelette the way i like it; rather than the common scrambled eggs that are often too hard and cold and tasting stale. i stayed at Heron's Landing again in january, 2020, and it was again the nicest, most friendly and accommodating hotel in the area. it is reasonably priced and all of the staff that i have met are superior. i have finally found my home away from home in Campbell River!

title: The Acropolis Museum is a great addition!
text: i have been to the Acropolis twice -- several years apart. Once i went to the museum and once i did not. the museum was a great addition to my knowledge and appreciation. i highly recommend it.

title: Acropolis is a must go to!
text:
The Acropolis is a major site in Athens. it can be seen from many spots in the city, but
going and being there up close is necessary to feel it and how things were in its heyday.

it can be crowded, sometimes the ground is not flat and tripping is possible, so be careful. it is definitely worth going to.

title: Delphi day trip from Athens worth the cost
text: i wanted to take my two teenager granddaughters and it seemed a regular tour of a large group in a bus would not be the best. through the tour company we were able to have a devoted driver and guide whose english and knowledge was wonderful. it was a good day with time to be outside and also in the museum. they guided us to a lovely place to have lunch. it was definitely worth the price.

title: united airline - one of the world's worst
text: i paid a lot of money to be comfortable on the long flight. my seat was broken and there wasn't another available. the attendants were not kind nor caring to help me in my situation. afterward i asked for a refund of the extra business class cost but was told that since i had made the trip they didn't need to offer me anything more. very inconsiderate, very impolite, very disrespectful. i had not flown united for many years because i thought they were nasty in the past. i have been reaffirmed and hope to never do business with united again.

title: Daishin-in in Myoshinji Temple Complex
text: I highly recommend staying at Daishin-in in the Myoshinji complex in the northwest area of Kyoto, which has many various temples within walking distance. The tatami rooms are lovely and the gardens are beautiful and peaceful. it is reasonably inexpensive and consequently difficult to reserve a room there at times. the breakfast is one of the best i've ever had in japan. I try to reserve a space there each time i go to kyoto.

title: Iwaso - one of the oldest ryokans in japan
text: Iwaso is located in one of the most beautiful spots in Japan...Miyajima. it takes a little bit to get there--by ferry, and it is worth the trouble. The ryokan is situated in a beautiful park and near some wonderful temples and shrines. The food there is very fine and the staff of the ryokan is very caring and courteous. One alert: be careful of the deer in the park. they can be very aggressive in wanting your food and other items. I highly recommend it.

title: Ryoanji
text:
Ryoanji Temple is a wonderful example of the concept of Zen Buddhism in Japan.
The temple and its gardens are very special and a clear statement of the art and history.
It is also very popular and sometimes much too crowded and busy. i highly recommend
trying to go there early (they are open at 8:30) or later, at the end of the day. the main rock garden is the popular attraction, but don't miss the other gardens and spaces in the
complex.

title: Arashiyama is a wonderful place to visit and get out of the busy city
text:
it is a joy to walk along the river. in summer children love to light fireworks where one can see the firework and the reflection at the same time. twice as much fun and beauty.
autumn is a wondrous time with the leaf colors. there are many restaurants...many expensive though. a great day trip away from the buzz of kyoto city.

title: Tenryuji
text: Tenryuji is a wonderful Rinzai Zen temple complex in the Arashiyama area. the gardens are magnificent in any season.

title: Philosopher's walk is lovely any season
text:
The Philosopher's Walk is a pedestrian path that follows a tree-lined canal in Kyoto, between two major temples: Ginkaku-ji and Nanzen-ji. It is a path good for a leisurely-paced 30-minute walk with small shops and stops along the way. Especially beautiful
during cherry blossom - spring and red maple tree -autumn times, it is ultimately a very
good walk any time of the year.

title: Kinkakuji Temple is a bit gaudy.
text:
i have been to kyoto many times. the first time i was there i visited Kinkakuji and even though it is beautiful it did not move me as much as other places. it is solem, it is
beautiful, it is usually crowded with tourists. i have not returned. there are so many
other wonderful sites to visit in kyoto!

title: Kiyomizu-dera has wonderful views!
text:
Kiyomizu-dera is in a very interesting section of Kyoto with many various ceramic studios. consequently the small streets that surround the temple are filled with shops that sell many different
styles of ceramics. that, along with the magnificent views from the temple, makes this a good trip and scenic experience.

title: Sanjusangendo Temple is one of the most wonderful places in kyoto!
text: Sanjusangendo Temple is my most favorite and go-to place in Kyoto. i have been to Kyoto many times and every chance i get i go to Sanjusangendo. i have even walked from Kyoto Station just to have a short time there. it is a reasonable 20 minute walking distance from the station. to see the many, many 1,001 various statues of Kannon (Kuan Yin), the Compassionate Buddha or Goddess of Mercy, is a thrill. they are all alike and all different. the building it is in is also notable. at almost 400 feet it is the longest wooden building in japan and has been used for archery contests for ages. Don't miss Sanjusangendo!

title: Ninna-ji Temple
text: Ninna-ji Temple in Kyoto is a very nice example of a city temple with reasonable grounds. there are some old structures throughout the property.

title: Toji -- a wonderful pagoda
text:
Toji is a great example of pagoda. it is right in the middle of kyoto and not a far walk from kyoto station. it is easily seen from many places in kyoto. most especial is the Toji market,
on the grounds the 21st of each month.

title: Beautiful, serene Ginkakuji-temple
text: Ginkaku-ji Temple is a beautiful, serene, elegant temple in a lovely section of Kyoto. it is at the end of the Philosophers' Walk and is usually a calm and pleasant visit.

title: Myoshinji Temple
text: Myoshinji is actually a complex of many temples in an area that is surrounded by a wall. there are private temples, some are open to the public. it is always a pleasant walk amongst the temples.

title: the flight attendants were not attendant.
text: my original flight was cancelled and i was not informed. the flight i finally was on did not have any attendants who were caring for the passengers. it was a long and uncomfortable flight.

title: taqueria los Abuelos is one of the best restaurants in Yelapa
text:
i have been to Yelapa five times and am thrilled that there is a restaurant as good as
Los Abuelos. i have taken many people and no one as ever been disappointed. their tacos and other regular offerings are very fine. i am a vegetarian and so the quality of
the salads are important to me. they are now open for lunch (sometimes) and that is
a wonderful addition. the drinks are strong. sometimes they get very crowded. the last two years we would come 1/2 hour before their opening so as to be sure we'd get seated. this year it has not been such a crowd. i highly recommend Los Abuelos!!!
their food is excellent and the prices are surprisingly inexpensive.

title: Cafe Bahia - an excellent choice for breakfast or brunch
text:
Cafe Bahia is my other favorite place to eat in Yelapa. the food is always fresh and good. the salads are wonderful. their Jugo Verde (green drink) is great. it is mostly a breakfast/brunch place. on sundays the Eggs Benedict or Florentine (for vegetarians) is wonderful. the everyday omelets are excellent and the bread served with them is delicious. everything i have ordered at Cafe Bahia has been fine. Susan is an extraordinarily fine host and cook. her granola is the best i've had. she is always friendly and able to spend time talking and dispensing information. the staff at Bahia
is also special. they all speak english and are able to accommodate special requests
when possible. i went in one day long after the lunch menu closed and asked if i could
have a salad. the waitress was able to get me one. also one day the juice was not
listed but another waitress was able to make me one. they are very kind and helpful.

title: Casa Isabel - a very special place in Yelapa
text: i have been to Yelapa five times and this is the first time i've stayed at Casa Isabel. I am so grateful that i've discovered it! the other times i was more in the busy part of Yelapa and here, on the point, it is quieter but not a far walk into the town. each time i have come i have brought students and taught a workshop. i am so glad to have found this beautiful natural spot. the pavilion at Casa Isabel is the most perfect place to hold my workshops. the view of the ocean is extraordinary and it is also shaded and protected. we've seen whales in the distance and a fine beach is just below. all of the various casitas have different feelings...people will like different ones. i have stayed here for a month this time, only one week was teaching. i will come here again and hope to hold my workshops here for a long time into the future.

title: El Manguito
text:
The restaurant is lovely. the walk to it is very interesting and easy. the owner and chef is
very friendly and nice and speaks good english. i have been to El Manguito several times over the past 5 years and it seems as if the quality of the cooking has lowered a bit. most of my friends had fish and were satisfied with it. i always order the chile rellenos, but it seems that it is not as good as it has been in the past. perhaps just a
lapse that will not be there again. the guacamole is great. EM is definitely worth trying.

title: Sakya Abode - a good place to stay
text: we stayed for three days. the service was always fine. the people who work there are very friendly. the owner was kind and helpful. the food was very good. it was a good place to come back to at the end of the day. the common area with books, etc., was a good place to drink tea and talk with others.

title: a lovely hotel but too far away from everything
text:
we had trouble finding a hotel room for new years eve. Gracious Bagan Hotel was the only availability and we were grateful to find it. when we arrived from the boat none of the drivers knew of the hotel and certainly did not want to take us there...wherever it was.
a driver eventually took us to some young drivers who were willing to try...for a huge price. the drive was very long; i was worried. they did not know where they were going but we finally arrived.
the hotel is lovely. the breakfast offerings were abundant and fine.
when we hired drivers or tour guides they were not attentive nor did they arrive on time. basically, if you do not have your own vehicle, transportation is very difficult.
the foot massage at the spa is very good.

title: good thai restaurant
text:
we went early and so were the only people there for dinner.
i'm a vegetarian and am very careful regarding vegetables.
the food was good, simple, and the service was attentive.

title: good burmese food
text: this restaurant is very popular and therefore crowded and noisy. when we arrived we were asked if we had reservations. we hadn't but they seated us anyway...at a table with another party. it was not a problem. the food was good but we couldn't feel that we wanted to linger.

title: wonderful, must go in Yangon
text:
everyone visiting Yangon must spend some time at Shwedagon.
a short while or the entire day ...whichever you like.
people watching is supreme.
make sure, like at all temples/pagodas, that you observe the clothing requirements.

title: Very interesting and most important: support young people in their endeavors.
text:
the program is by the Inwa School of Performing Arts which brings students in from the countryside and supports and educates them in the traditional arts of Myanmar. the classical music was wonderful (performed by adults) and the dancers were engaging.
there were only two paying customers there that night. please go, the performance is only one hour, and let the students and teachers know you support them.

title: good thai food in mandalay
text:
i ate at the vegetarian restaurant one night and noticed the Rain Forest right across the street. the next night i ate at the Rain Forest and enjoyed it very much. their honey, lemon, ginger drink was the best i had in all of myanmar. their vegetable curry
was delicious. the ambiance was quiet and lovely and i enjoyed the various curios under the glass tops of the tables. i recommend Rain Forest.

title: THE WORLD'S LARGEST BOOK
text: This was a beautiful place to visit...especially on a hot day...it seemed to be cooler than the other places in the area. it is amazing to realize how much work it took to engrave all and each of these slabs and all the words and scriptures.
place: Kuthodaw Pagoda & the World's Largest Book

title: Mandalay Hill
text: Mandalay Hill was a huge walk up...didn't count the steps, but they were numerous with seating possible all the way along. beautiful at the top. it was definitely worth it.

title: A wonderful place to stay with very kind staff
text:
The Delphi Art Hotel was by far the very best of five different hotels i stayed in this time in Greece. The staff was very kind and accommodating. When i misunderstood their quote of price of a room they honored my understanding; when i returned for my second stay and they didn't have a room that i asked for they upgraded me to a suite and didn't charge me more.

The hotel is small and very comfortable. It is located in the central area of Athens, so easy to get to by metro and within walking distance of some of the premium attractions.

The breakfast offerings are fine and plentiful. The rooms are very comfortable.
The staff was helpful and attentive to my various requests and needs.

I will definitely return to the Delphi Art Hotel whenever i am in Athens!

title: top rated hotel with low accommodations for guests
text:
Titania Hotel is large and one of the highest rated hotels in athens, greece.
i found it to be very expensive for what they offered. the breakfast offerings were good and plentiful, but the rest was meager: room cleaning service was very slow and didn't happen until quite late in the day. prices in the restaurant and coffee shop were very high. the most upsetting situation is that there is no wi-fi in the rooms. one can purchase wi-fi to be in their rooms but it is expensive and not very good or fast. there is free wi-fi only in the lobby of this big, busy hotel. almost any time of the day or night people are huddled on the few sitting places and trying to connect on their devices. the connection is very, very slow and sometimes doesn't happen at all. this is not a generous offering to the guests who are paying top money to stay there.
